name: Conway's thrackle conjecture
rephrased: In any thrackle drawing (where edges meet exactly once at vertices or cross properly), the number of edges cannot exceed the number of vertices.
implication_form: If a graph can be drawn as a thrackle, then it must have at most as many edges as vertices.
explained: Conway's thrackle conjecture states that any graph which has a thrackle drawing (a drawing in the plane where every pair of edges meets exactly once, either at a common endpoint or at a proper crossing) must satisfy the condition that the number of edges is at most the number of vertices. In other words, a thrackleable graph (one that admits a thrackle drawing) can have no more edges than vertices.
